segments.key_quote: It can destroy a whole universe that is the kind of power this Brahmastra has.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the context of Srimad Bhagavatam 1.7.20, focusing on Ashwathama's use of the Brahmastra and its destructive power.
segments.transcript: Athopas Prishya Salilam Sandadhetat Samahitah Ajanan Api Samharam Prana Krishra Upasthite. The meaning of this verse as translated by Srila Prabhupada: Since his life was in danger, he touched water in sanctity and concentrated upon the chanting of the hymns for throwing nuclear weapons, although he did not know how to withdraw such weapons. So, the description is that Ashwathama, when he realized his life was in danger after he had beheaded the five sleeping sons of Draupadi, and he wanted to please his master Duryodhana, and Duryodhana was not at all pleased with this act of Ashwathama, and Arjuna, when he learned from Draupadi that Ashwathama has killed her sons, five sleeping sons, then Arjuna vowed to punish this Ashwathama. So, Arjuna started chasing Ashwathama, and Ashwathama was trying to escape, but his horse became tired. On the horseback, his horse became tired, and he realized he can't go any further, and Arjuna is chasing on a chariot, and Arjuna is accompanied by Krishna, who was acting as the Sarathi, the chariot driver of Arjuna. This towards the end of the battle of Kurukshetra. So, this verse describes that this Ashwathama, since his life was in danger, he decided to use the ultimate weapon, the Brahmastra, to protect his son from the evil of the Kurukshetra, and he decided to use the ultimate weapon, the Brahmastra, to protect himself, and he did not have complete knowledge of using this Brahmastra weapon. He knew how to release this weapon, but he did not know how to withdraw it, so he didn't have complete knowledge, and it is, it is like a nuclear weapon. Srila Prabhupada explains this Brahmastra is like a nuclear weapon, it has got tremendous amount of radiation that is generated. And what is the kind of power of this Brahmastra?
